Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An investigation of wave dynamics in the Arctic mesosphere and coupling between the lower and upper polar atmosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective is to utilize a suite of instruments, including
an airglow imager, to investigate short-period
gravity waves in the Arctic atmosphere over Alaska. Short-period
gravity waves are an important component of the larger atmospheric
circulation as these waves are believed to transport a large amount of
vertical moment flux into the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT)
region. While the propagation nature and sources of these waves have
been studied extensively at low- and mid-latitudes, little is known about their behavior at high latitudes. Recent efforts have
begun to characterize the waves over the Antarctic continent, while
the project proposed here will focus on the Arctic. Specifically, the
proposed research will establish a long-term winter time series of
short-period gravity waves in the Arctic, including their dominant
source regions, and influences of large-scale tidal and planetary wave
motion. The co-located Rayleigh lidar will provide essential high
vertical resolution temperature measurements to help elucidate the
vertical wave propagation, individual wave contribution to the
Eliassen-Palm (EP) flux, and coupling between the lower and upper
atmosphere during stratospheric warming events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The typical average temperature in our atmosphere is the result of combined energy gains (mostly form our sun) and loses. During the daytime the surface is heated up and our atmosphere warms, while in the nighttime, it cools down. The temperature differences create large wind systems in the atmosphere, very much alike to motion in a cup of coffee when mixed with cream. However, there are variations in the temperature and winds that are the results of small waves propagating through the atmosphere. These waves are termed atmospheric gravity waves and are typically created when winds flow across mountains and hills, or when water vapor condenses in large tropical storms or thunderstorms. The later process is the opposite of boiling water. When boiling water energy must be added to the system, while the opposite process (condensation) release energy. The released energy from a tropical storm gives rise to wave motion in the atmosphere.

These waves are of crucial importance to understand our atmosphere, improve weather prediction, and understand our climate. Unfortunately, some of the most important waves are relatively small (tens of miles) and are difficult to include in weather and climate models. Instead, the models take the effect of the waves and implement that into the models instead of the waves themselves. The majority of our knowledge of the waves comes from observations near equator or from mid latitudes, while very little is known of the waves over the Polar Regions. This project address this lack of knowledge by deploying a specially designed camera to detect waves high in the atmosphere (~60 miles up) over interior Alaska. In coordination with this camera are two other instruments: a laser system capable of measuring waves between ~20-60 miles in altitude, and a novel radar system measuring the waves in our near-space environment from ~60 miles and up to 200 miles in altitude. With these instruments, we are able to characterize the waves over a large altitude range, determine their variability, and how they couple between atmospheric layers across the 20-200 mile altitude range. Of particular interest is how major weather phenomena such as sudden stratospheric warming (SSW) events are impacting these waves.

The key instrument in the project, an airglow imager, was acquired in 2010 and installed in Alaska in January 2011. Since then the imager has collected high-quality data revealing an impressive amount of wave activity. The major findings of the project showed a seasonal variation not seen at other observation sites. This variability was determined to be due to diminishing winds in the atmosphere below the observation point (at altitudes below 60 miles). Furthermore, the SSW was shown to have minor impact on the waves observed with the imager. In contrast, the lidar system has shown that the stratospheric waves (20-50 miles) are heavily influenced by the SSW events. Up higher in the atmosphere, the radar revealed a completely different scenario, suggesting that the waves observed with the imager does not make it into the higher atmosphere. Instead, the waves observed by the radar are most likely waves produced at high altitudes. These results are essential for our further understanding of atmospheric dynamics and will provide the modeling community with important information regarding atmospheric coupling and energy balance.

The project provided training and support for a large number of students. A total of five undergraduate and eight graduate students have been working and making significant contributions to the project. The acquired instrument continues to make excellent measurements and is an integral part of training and educating undergraduate students at Utah Valley University.
